issues.title: is "*foo.example.com" allowed or just "*.example.com"
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
WebPKI says just the latter. Browsers seem to do just the latter. OpenSSL allows the former, and then some.
WG needs to decide.

comments.author: sleevi
comments.body: See also https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6125#section-7.2

issues.title: Remove block-quote text "> foo..."
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body: There are two instances of block quote text and both can be easily removed.  One is an example in `#verify-reference-rules` and the other is a security warning in `#verify-outcome-fallback`

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: There are also two "implementation note" sections which can just be removed.

issues.title: Use more "proposed standard" language
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
6125 was a survey of what a whole bunch of protocols did.
This document should be a set of MUST that protocols should do.

This should be able to give simpler wording. For example "specifications that reference this document" and the like can be dropped in favor of all-caps language.

issues.title: Pete and Jeff have/had ideas
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
There were things that the 6125 authors, Pete and Jeff, wanted to put into their document but didn't feel that they could.

This issue captures that to-do item.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: The only thing I really recall was our desire to actively discourage or prohibit wildcard certificates. However, it seems that we still don't have consensus to make such a radical change.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Yeah, we definitely don't have consensus to prohibit. There are more warnings in the current draft, and I think that's all we can do about wildcards.  (Oh also, it's only "*.foo.bar" none of the more complicated patterns.)  So perhaps close this?

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: Yes, I'm closing this. :-)

From Peter: P.S. In the version of the document we should include an appendix
documenting the changes from RFC 6125.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/errata/eid5673  Suggests a minor wording change and is done in #27

issues.title: Make spec work for peer-to-peer not just client-server
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
Comment from Brian on the UTA list June 1:
   I think we should avoid mentioning roles like "client" or "server" except non-normatively to emphasize that the spec would apply to both roles. What matters is that the entity's identity is a DNS name.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body:
In the same thread, John Mattson said
- Some sections mention "server" while other sections does not state anything, therefor applying to both client and server. I think the draft needs to be very clear on this point.
- client certs are built with CN and cannot be easily changed. Other uses of RFC 6125 like the Service Based Architecture in 3GPP 5G makes little or no difference between server and client when it comes to certificates.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: The terminology of client and server in RFC 6125 refers to TLS clients and servers, which seems perfectly appropriate. Even in a peer-to-peer architecture, for any given TLS interaction one entity will be the TLS client and one will be the TLS server.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Yeah, I get that it comes from TLS and that's fine.  But should make more clear, I think, that the server can validate the client identity (if presented)  As the text says "mutual TLS auth is ... [not often done] ..."

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Going to close this as at least the draft now makes an overall statement. I don't think we should change all uses of client and server since, as @stpeter said, it's the terminology used in TLS.  If there are specific uses that are wrong, we can fix those if they're pointed out.

issues.title: Those using TLS as service?
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
QUIC uses TLS to set up crypto keys. Implementations use the same TLS code, generally to validate the certifificate.

NTS uses TLS similarly including the TLS validation code.

How to mention these? and say that future services should do the same thing?

Or something.

issues.title: Results of "Cited By" Review
issues.author: stpeter
issues.body:
I've completed a review of the 75 RFCs that cite RFC 6125: https://www.arkko.com/tools/allstats/citations-rfc6125.html

Of these, I have slight concerns about only 3:

* RFC 8071 discusses a function that enables servers to call out to clients; in this case the very concept of a reference identifier doesn't apply, but I don't see the need to modify 6125bis to cover this use case.
* RFC 8314 discusses pinned certificates and points to RFC 6125 for further discussion about pinning; although we're removing this text from 6125bis, the pointer to RFC 6125 will remain valid.
* RFC 9174 defines a new certificate identifier "NODE-ID"; because this appears to be specific to delay-tolerant networking, I don't think we need to add it to 6125bis.

Comments welcome.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: I'm closing this because we discussed it on list.

issues.title: third-party domain mapping
issues.author: stpeter
issues.body:
I'm not really sure what this means (in Section 6.1.1):

> or obtaining the data from a third-
>  party domain mapping service in which a human user has explicitly
>  placed trust and with which the client communicates over a connection
>  or association that provides both mutual authentication and integrity
>  checking

Therefore I wonder if we ought to delete it.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body:
It was intended to capture this from 6125:
```
The client may map the reference identity to a different type prior
   to performing a comparison.  Mappings may be performed for all
   available subjectAltName types to which the reference identity can be
   mapped; however, the reference identity should only be mapped to
   types for which the mapping is either inherently secure (e.g.,
   extracting the DNS name from a URI to compare with a subjectAltName
   of type dNSName) or for which the mapping is performed in a secure
   manner (e.g., using [DNSSEC], or using user- or admin-configured
   host-to-address/address-to-host lookup tables).
```

I *think* :)  Perhaps I made it too terse?

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: Well, we had the same text in Section 6.2.1 of RFC 6125. I just don't recall what we meant by a third-party domain mapping service that's not DNS. @equalsJeffH do you remember?

comments.author: equalsJeffH
comments.body:
>we had the same text in Section 6.2.1 of RFC 6125.

the latter is the same "Rules" section as Section 6.1.1 of RFC6125, so the text @stpeter is quoting is simply carried over from the former to the latter.

Thus I doubt it has anything to do with the text @richsalz quotes. Besides, that latter text is from RFC6125 appendix B "LDAP" and is a quoted section from [LDAP-AUTH].

Regarding what the "obtaining the data from a third-party domain mapping service" text @stpeter quotes might mean, the only thing I can think of that we might have been thinking of and hand-waving about at the time is some sort of a DANE-based resolution service perhaps run by the Registries/Registrars.  Or perhaps we were thinking of some sort(s) of enterprise-based domain mapping service(s).  The text does not disallow whatever-it/they-might-be from being based on DNS.  Or perhaps we were simply covering our bases, ie future-proofing, such that if something like that existed for some reader(s) (we might've even been thinking of some sort of enterprise use case, but this why the "third-party" stipulation?), then we addressed it.  (now I'm hand-waving ;-)

So, whatever sort of use case(s) we were allowing for has not emerged over the last decade, so perhaps we should go ahead and delete it, I'm fine with that.

HTH, =JeffH

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: Perhaps it was intended to cover DANE or some kind of enterprise mapping service. In either case, it appears that such services have not come into being since RFC 6125 was published, so I'm in favor of removing the text. It's more likely to cause confusion than enlightenment.

issues.title: Better description around ALPACA
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
Taken from https://github.com/richsalz/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/pull/33#discussion_r834900755 by @martinthomson :

There is no normative language about having the same versions and configuration (it's also key exchange methods, by the way), which is OK, but only if you explain why this is the case. We make this suggestion because a deployment that can be attacked in this way might be vulnerable based on the weakest configuration it is willing to negotiate. Though TLS guarantees that a connection will choose the server's choice from mutually-supported features, in a cross-protocol attack the attack might steer clients toward a server that has a weaker configuration.

The SHOULD on ALPN is really the crux of the cross-protocol defense though. the key is that ALPN provides an authenticated way for the client and server to agree on the protocol that is in use. that trumps anything else here. if you have that, then the crypto configuration stuff is more or less pointless.

I would commit to doing this properly by starting a new section on how to manage the cross-protocol thing. Focus on ALPACA there. Not doing ALPN is only OK to the extent that the protocols that might be used cannot be misinterpreted and that's not an easy thing to guarantee, thanks to "robust" or creative interpretation of protocol elements being commonplace.

For this section, concentrate on the SNI issue. Not doing SNI is mostly OK in protocols that unambiguously identify the identity they are using (HTTP's Host header field, for instance). Not doing SNI in protocols without clear identity signals in-protocol - signals that are really used, everywhere - is just as bad as not doing ALPN.

The DROWN thing is definitely a risk, but DROWN was due to the configuration including options that were too weak to ensure that the TLS guarantee. You might mention DROWN and emphasize that certain types of weakness in crypto can undermine the guarantee TLS provides about its negotiation of parameters, but it doesn't really belong here from what I can see.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: It seems to me that we might be verging into the territory of TLS itself rather than certificate checking in the context of TLS. For example, Sections 3.7 and 3.8 of rfc7525bis mention ALPACA and Section 3.8 in particular discusses ALPN. @martinthomson I'm curious to hear your thoughts on the division of responsibilities between these documents.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Hmm, if there is work on ALPACA already in RFC 7525(bis), then the text in this document can probably just reference it.  The ALPN text in 7525bis seems like it gets most of the way.

What RFC7525bis lacks is talk about the risk arising from inconsistent configuration in a multi-server deployment.  For cross-protocol attacks, that is especially relevant for ALPN and for identity confusion it is relevant to SNI.  DROWN exploited inconsistent (and weak) ciphersuite configuration, which opens servers up to essentially unbounded attacks, which only include protocol confusion and impersonation.

What this document needs to discuss is the use of certificates.  I think that it is reasonable to say that the set of names you put in a certificate is the set of names that is affected by any compromise of a server with those names.  It's a shared attack surface that spans all services that share those names.  The strength of any server in that set is determined by the weakest of those that offer those names.  The way to mitigate this risk is to limit the names that any server can speak for and to ensure that servers have a strong minimum configuration, citing RFC7525bis.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body:
> Hmm, if there is work on ALPACA already in RFC 7525(bis), then the text in this document can probably just reference it. The ALPN text in 7525bis seems like it gets most of the way.

Sure we can put an informative link to that draft.

> What this document needs to discuss is the use of certificates. I think that it is reasonable to say that the set of names you put in a certificate is the set of names that is affected by any compromise of a server with those names. It's a shared attack surface that spans all services that share those names. The strength of any server in that set is determined by the weakest of those that offer those names. The way to mitigate this risk is to limit the names that any server can speak for and to ensure that servers have a strong minimum configuration, citing RFC7525bis.

Thanks for this (and for understanding what the focus of *this* draft is). I believe this text can be tweaked and put into the security considerations as a general issue for SAN names. I'll prepare a PR to do this today.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Fixed by #46, closing this.

issues.title: reg-name in URIs
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
The following text appears in [Section 6.2](https://richsalz.github.io/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis.html#section-6.2-3.3):

> Matching only the "reg-name" rule from [[URI](https://richsalz.github.io/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis.html#URI)] limits verification to DNS domain names, thereby differentiating a URI-ID from a uniformResourceIdentifier entry that contains an IP address or a mere host name, or that does not contain a "host" component at all.

This is not correct.  reg-name covers every type of hostname that isn't an IP address.  This includes DNS domain names, but it also includes other types of names ("a mere host name").  I plan to replace this text in #54, but I wanted to flag this separately.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body:
You are correct that this is an error, since the reg-name construction is defined as follows:

> reg-name    = *( unreserved / pct-encoded / sub-delims )

I'd suggest changing the text to:

> Matching only the "reg-name" rule from [URI] differentiates a URI-ID from a uniformResourceIdentifier entry that contains a host component matching the IP-literal rule or IPv4address rule.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: That text looks good.  We can make the change during AD/IESG review.

comments.author: aamelnikov
comments.body:
After seeing that RFC 3986 contains:

   host        = IP-literal / IPv4address / reg-name

I agree.

issues.title: Clarify how reference identifiers are created
issues.author: stpeter
issues.body: This issue surfaced during discussion of https://github.com/richsalz/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/pull/54 - see discussion thread there for details.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body:
Copying the other thread here for full context...

The document talks about reference identifiers, but doesn't really go into much detail about how those are created. I think that you already have much of what you need in Section 6.1.1.

Where it says:

The client might need to extract the source domain and application service type from the input(s) it has received.

You might instead say:

This document doesn't precisely define how reference identifiers are derived.Applications that use this document need to define how reference identifiers are determined. The security of a system that uses this document will depend on how reference identifiers are obtained.

Then back to the existing language:

Naturally, if the inputs themselves are invalid or corrupt (e.g., a user has clicked a link provided by a malicious entity in a phishing attack), then the client might end up communicating with an unexpected application service.

Then for this text, we have a case where the system might handle an identifier that looks like a reference identifier, but it isn't. What we're really saying here is:

During the course of processing, a client might be exposed to identifiers that look like reference identifiers. For example, DNS resolution that starts at a DNS-ID reference identifier might produce intermediate domain names that need to be further resolved.

Any intermediate values are not reference identifiers and MUST NOT be treated as such, except as defined by the application. In the DNS case, not treating intermediate domain names as reference identifiers removes DNS and DNS resolution from the attack surface. An application might define a process for authenticating these intermediate identifiers in a way that then allows them to be used as a reference identifier; see for example {{?RFC8689}}.

issues.title: 08 (or its equivalent)
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
> The scheme MUST be that of the protocol associated with the application service type and the "host" component (or its equivalent) MUST be the FQDN of the service.

Not sure I understand this part, but it feels like an underspecified MUST.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: It seems that this text was also in RFC 6125, but I cannot recall why. In URI syntax, there is no "equivalent" of a host component (i.e., nothing else allowed in an authority component that serves the same purpose as the host component). Therefore I suggest that we remove "(or its equivalent)".

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: I agree with removal.

issues.title: Section 3 cleanup
issues.author: stpeter
issues.body:
§3 states:

> A protocol can allow the use of an IP address in place of a DNS name.
   This might use the same field without distinguishing the type of
   identifier, see for example [URI].  In this case, applications need
   to be aware that the textual representation of an IPv4 address can
   appear to be a valid DNS name, though it is not.  The two types can
   be distinguished by first testing if the identifier is a valid IPv4
   address.  Note also that by policy, Top-Level Domains ([DNS-TERMS])
   do not start with a digit (TODO: citation needed).

It's not clear to me what @martinthomson had in mind with "the textual representation of an IPv4 address can appear to be a valid DNS name" - perhaps an example would help?

Also, we need a citation for "by policy, Top-Level Domains do not start with a digit". Perhaps https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3696#section-2 would fit the bill?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
"192.0.2.10" is technically a valid LDH domain name.  So is "192.0x20a" (the same address).  That there are no valid DNS names with a TLD containing all digits does not appear to be codified anywhere.  I remember something in an ICANN document I read once, but navigating their documents requires dark arts I'm not versed in.

That RFC 3696 thing is a bit weak, but it might do in a pinch.  The problems being:

1. There is is just a single parenthetical "(including verification that the apparent TLD name is not all-numeric)" along these lines.
2. It is extremely wordy.
3. It is old and crufty.  I mean, you have to get past a short list of non-CC TLDs that were valid in 2003, which in 2022 drains the text of all authority.
4. It is not complete.  Hex strings are not digits (at least as envisaged in that document).

I would advocate for a direct quote if you use that, with some explanation along these lines.

What I was thinking when I wrote that text was that I wanted to avoid burdening the reader with all the gory details, and myself with the need to write a whole bunch of text and then organize it in some fashion that didn't ruin the flow of the document.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body:
Another possibility is to cite RFC 3986:

> The syntax rule for host is ambiguous because it does not completely
   distinguish between an IPv4address and a reg-name.  In order to
   disambiguate the syntax, we apply the "first-match-wins" algorithm:
   If host matches the rule for IPv4address, then it should be
   considered an IPv4 address literal and not a reg-name.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body:
Moreover, §2.3.1 of RFC 1035 does state:

> The labels must follow the rules for ARPANET host names.  They must
start with a letter, end with a letter or digit, and have as interior
characters only letters, digits, and hyphen.  There are also some
restrictions on the length.  Labels must be 63 characters or less.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: @martinthomson When you get a chance, I'm curious to hear your thoughts on the proposed text in the pull request.

issues.title: Browser behavior
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
The draft currently treats the WHATWG/browser behavior as an "alternative", but I think almost everything on the public internet works this way.

```
Although the reader should be aware that some applications (e.g., web browsers) might instead conform
to the Uniform Resource Locator (URL) specification maintained by the WHATWG [[URL]
(https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-10.html#URL)],
it is not expected that differences between the URI and URL specifications would manifest themselves in
certificate matching.
```

That's a little misleading, and contradicted by the IDNA section just below. There are names valid under `UTS-46` that aren't valid under `IDNA2008`.  The Postfix example given by Viktor Dukhovni is a good one:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/uta/Nb_tFen5lDfoGoOgedwNS2KDc8A/

He says "To find substantially different practice, you probably need to look at industrial automation networks, and some IoT applications". That line of argument is definitely a pet peeve of mine, but I think it shows that that the browser way is what's really used.

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: Take it to the list.

issues.title: IP address octets
issues.author: sayrer
issues.body:
The draft says:

```
An IP address is either a 4-octet IPv4 address [[IPv4](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-10.html#IPv4)] or a 16-octet IPv6 address [[IPv6](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-10.html#IPv6)]. The identifier might need to be converted from a textual representation to obtain this value.
```

I think it should not mention the octet count, since this count is not necessarily true of IPv6 addresses (and does not appear in the IPv6 RFC). Suggested edit:

```
An IP address is either an IPv4 address [[IPv4](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-10.html#IPv4)] or an IPv6 address [[IPv6](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-10.html#IPv6)]. The identifier might need to be converted from a textual representation to obtain this value.
```

IPv6 addresses have all sorts of abbreviation mechanisms. I wrote this code, and it isn't quite right, although it's good enough for now:
https://github.com/sayrer/twitter-text/blob/cxx/rust/parser/src/twitter_text.pest#L166

It doesn't get zone indices right, but no one seems to care.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: I strongly disagree. IPaddresses, like DNS names, should be in canonical format when in certificates.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
Well, I get what you're saying here, I think. But, this is actually a total mess. For example, one might read

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5952#section-4

and see the words "A recommendation for a canonical text representation format of IPv6 addresses is presented in this section." So, then the closing sentence "The identifier might need to be converted from a textual representation to obtain this value." is unclear.

issues.title: Éric Vyncke's feedback (1 or 2): SVCB
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
I find this document update useful ***BUT*** it lacks the support of the new
SVCB (draft-ietf-dnsop-svcb-https)... May I recommend that this document is
sent back to the WG in order to incorporate the SCVB (it is very similar to SRV
IMHO)? I appreciate that the SVCB started in a different WG hence the
disconnect even if some authors of the two I-Ds have the same affiliation ;-) I
added the SVCB authors in copy to this ballot, just in case.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: I will be talking with Mike Bishop (one of the authors rumored to work at Akamai:) in a day or two about this.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body:
At least for HTTPS the SVCB record does not have the same special-handling that SRV has.
In particular, the draft in the RFC editor queue (draft-ietf-dnsop-svcb-https-12) has:

> Note that none of these forms alter the origin or authority for validation purposes. For example, TLS clients MUST continue to validate TLS certificates for the original service name.
> ...
> Note that none of these forms alter the HTTPS origin or authority. For example, clients MUST continue to validate TLS certificate hostnames based on the origin.
> ...
> Similar to CNAME, HTTPS RRs have no impact on the origin name. When connecting, clients will continue to treat the authoritative origins as "https://www.aliased.example" and "https://aliased.example", respectively, and will validate TLS server certificates accordingly.

For HTTPS RRs it's pretty clear that just DNS-IDs would be used in this case and that AliasMode and TargetNames would not have any influence.

It is an interesting point that while this is fairly clear for HTTPS RRs not using alternate ports, the SVCB draft is less clear on how this fits in or what is desirable for SVCB lookups of the form _8080._foo.example.com and what would be the "original service name" in that case.  Would these want to also be SRV-IDs?  

Even with HTTPS RRs with Web Origins on alternate ports (eg, "https://example.com:8443"), how to handle _8443._https.example.com is less clear.  To be non-breaking, example.com as a DNS-ID might still be needed.

Would it make sense to also allow the SRV-IDs in this case (eg, "_8080._foo.example.com") but to be clear that unlike SRV these don't carry through to TargetName and/or through AliasMode?

(It would be good to loop Ben Schwartz in here as well since he has thought about this part lots as well.  There may be people we want to include in the discussion for going past the HTTPS use-case.)

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Ping @bemasc

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Taking a deeper read through draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis, some of this may be generalizing to also be clear that protocols using SVCB (or SVCB-compatible record  types) need to define their validation rules and what identifiers are allowed.  (Similar to what the draft says for other protocols.)

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body:
Yes, I am thinking -- if only for simplicity -- we say something like this:
```
Anything other than a simple origin name is out of scope for this specification.
Protocols that use identifiers that look like SRV IDs, for example, must define their
own rules.
```

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
Defining WebPKI integration rules generally for all future protocols and ID types sounds very hard.

I'm not sure whether "https://example.com:12345" looks like an SRV ID (or a URI ID) or not, so I'm not sure what to make of that rule.

I think the truth is:

> Use of SVCB-compatible records during connection establishment does not alter any PKIX validation requirements unless the applicable SVCB mapping document states otherwise.  For example, the PKIX validation rules for HTTP over TLS {{?RFC2818}} and DNS over TLS {{?RFC7858}} do not change when the client uses HTTPS records {{?I-D.ietf-dnsop-svcb-https}} or SVCB for DNS {{?I-D.ietf-add-svcb-dns}}.

That's a bit squishy but anything else seems a bit speculative.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: @bemasc I like your suggestion.  @stpeter , do you want to make a PR that integrates this (and the appropriate refernces) or me?

comments.author: stpeter
comments.body: Yes, I will create a PR.

## Component or label ?

The text uses terms like `component of a domain name` while RFC 8499 (DNS
terminology) would prefer to use `label of a domain name`. Most parts of the
document correctly use 'labels' but there are some use of 'component'.

## Section 1.4.2

s/Certificates representing client identities other than as described above,
such as rfc822Name, are beyond the scope of this document/Certificates
representing client identities, such as rfc822Name, other than as described
above are beyond the scope of this document/ to simplify the parsing ?

# NITS

## Section 1.4.2

`for our purposes we care`, RFCs usually do not use a personal voice. But this
is a matter of taste.

issues.title: Proposed updates/clarifications
issues.author: enygren
issues.body:
Some comments on a read-through if not too late:

1) On DNS names starting with Labels:

> historically this rule was also intended to apply to all labels in a domain name (see [Section 2.3.1](https://rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc1035#section-2.3.1) of [[DNS-NAMES](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc1035)]), although that is not always the case in practice.

This should probably be more clear that domain names are explicitly allowed to start with digits.  As per  https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1123#section-2.1 and https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2181#section-11 clearly update this.  For example from the former clearly states:
"One aspect of host name syntax is hereby changed: the restriction on the first character is relaxed to allow either a letter or a digit.  Host software MUST support this more liberal syntax"

2) On the Web example:

>Consider a simple website at www.example.com, which is not discoverable via DNS SRV lookups. Because HTTP does not specify the use of URIs in server certificates, a certificate for this service might include only a DNS-ID of www.example.com.
> Consider the same website, which is reachable by a fixed IP address of 2001:db8::5c. The certificate might include this value in an IP-ID to allow clients to use the fixed IP address as a reference identity.

This would not be the same "website".  In particular, the web origin (rfc6454) is the tuple of scheme, authority, and port.  Since the authority is different (ie, the IP vs the hostname) they would be distinct.   If we're going to include this example, we should be clear that https://www.example.com/ and https://[2001:db8::5c]/ might be multi-tenant on the same server but are different web origins (ie, different "websites")

3) Example in 6.1.2 (nit)
Per https://www.iab.org/2016/11/07/iab-statement-on-ipv6/ it would also be worth including some more IPv6 examples in the examples (eg, for "https://[2001:db8::abcd]" as an example origin, perhaps augmenting the existing IPv4 examples so we always have both?)

4) Clarification on IP address matching
>For an IP address that appears in a URI-ID, the "host" component of both the reference identity and the presented identifier must match. These are parsed as either an "IP-literal" (following [[IPv6](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4291)]) or an "IPv4address" (following [[IPv4](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc791)]). If the resulting octets are equal, the IP address matches.

In the IPv6 case, it may be better to reference https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3986 section 3.2.2 since what is being matched isn't "IP-literal" (which is in square brackets) per the below ABNF but the address inside those brackets:

      IP-literal = "[" ( IPv6address / IPvFuture  ) "]"

There is also the case of https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6874 (which allows zoneids) but since the zoneid has host scope it makes no sense for it to be included in how certs are verified.  (But perhaps there should be a requirement that the IPv6 IP-ID address NOT be LinkLocal?)

issues.title: Lars's Feedback
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
Lars Eggert has entered the following ballot position for
draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-14: Discuss

When responding, please keep the subject line intact and reply to all
email addresses included in the To and CC lines. (Feel free to cut this
introductory paragraph, however.)


Please refer to https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://www.ietf.org/about/groups/iesg/statements/handling-ballot-positions/__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7uqdkd83$  
for more information about how to handle DISCUSS and COMMENT positions.


The document, along with other ballot positions, can be found here:
https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7v4MXsmZ$



----------------------------------------------------------------------
DISCUSS:
----------------------------------------------------------------------

# GEN AD review of draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-14

CC @larseggert

Thanks to Maria Ines Robles for the General Area Review Team (Gen-ART) review
(https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gen-art/kKymWzL6jRgmCfLhf0A8IJATMMQ__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7ojHWKPN$ ).

## Discuss

### Section 4.2, paragraph 4
```
     Consider a SIP-accessible voice-over-IP (VoIP) server at the host
     voice.example.edu servicing SIP addresses of the form
     [user@voice.example.edu](mailto:user@voice.example.edu) and identified by a URI of
     <sip:voice.example.edu>.  A certificate for this service would
     include a URI-ID of sip:voice.example.edu (see [SIP-CERTS]) along
     with a DNS-ID of voice.example.edu.
```
This has got to be the most pedantic Discuss ever, but
AFAICT "example.edu" is not in fact a valid example domain, i.e.,
it's missing from
https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://www.iana.org/assignments/special-use-domain-names/special-use-domain-names.xhtml__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7h3lbvvu$


----------------------------------------------------------------------
COMMENT:
----------------------------------------------------------------------

## Comments

### Inclusive language

Found terminology that should be reviewed for inclusivity; see
https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://www.rfc-editor.org/part2/*inclusive_language__;Iw!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7vzAs3Qk$  for background and more
guidance:

* Term `traditional`; alternatives might be `classic`, `classical`, `common`,
   `conventional`, `customary`, `fixed`, `habitual`, `historic`,
   `long-established`, `popular`, `prescribed`, `regular`, `rooted`,
   `time-honored`, `universal`, `widely used`, `widespread`

## Nits

All comments below are about very minor potential issues that you may choose to
address in some way - or ignore - as you see fit. Some were flagged by
automated tools (via https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://github.com/larseggert/ietf-reviewtool__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7lmUgeZH$ ), so there
will likely be some false positives. There is no need to let me know what you
did with these suggestions.

### Outdated references

Document references `draft-ietf-tls-subcerts`, but that has been published as
`RFC9345`.

### URLs

These URLs in the document can probably be converted to HTTPS:

*
https://urldefense.com/v3/__http://www.blackhat.com/presentations/bh-dc-09/Marlinspike/BlackHat-DC-09-Marlinspike-Defeating-SSL.pdf__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7ssUdH9o$

### Grammar/style

#### Section 4.1, paragraph 1
```
SIP as described in [SIP-SIPS]). Typically this identifier type would supple
                                 ^^^^^^^^^
```
A comma may be missing after the conjunctive/linking adverb "Typically".

#### Section 4.2, paragraph 4
```
s or IP-IDs. Again, because of multi-protocol attacks this practice is discou
                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
This word is normally spelled as one.

#### Section 6.2, paragraph 7
```
DNS domain names more generally. Therefore the use of wildcard characters as
                                  ^^^^^^^^^
```
A comma may be missing after the conjunctive/linking adverb "Therefore".

## Notes

This review is in the ["IETF Comments" Markdown format][ICMF], You can use the
[`ietf-comments` tool][ICT] to automatically convert this review into
individual GitHub issues. Review generated by the [`ietf-reviewtool`][IRT].

[ICMF]: https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://github.com/mnot/ietf-comments/blob/main/format.md__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7qw6u-pu$
[ICT]: https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://github.com/mnot/ietf-comments__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7irKxvr-$
[IRT]: https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://github.com/larseggert/ietf-reviewtool__;!!GjvTz_vk!Vit0YEVafKcpWsWbgd21mvFM66UC5HmMCKEYoPinyYlFR07SOF0rCUr83MYYcONKCIEn7lmUgeZH$

issues.title: Warren Kumari's feedback
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
----------------------------------------------------------------------
COMMENT:
----------------------------------------------------------------------

I almost balloted DISCUSS, simply to seize Lars' "most pedantic Discuss ever"
crown, but I decided that the entertainment potential wasn't really worth it:
"I think that the convention / standard terminology is "subject alternative
name" or "subjectAltName", not "subjectAlternativeName"."

Instead, because the document is so very readable, I'm balloting Yes.

Nits:
"TLS uses the words client and server, where the client is the entity that
initiates the connection." - this might be better as 'TLS uses the words
"client" and "server", where the client is the entity that initiates the
connection.'

"During the course of processing, a client might be exposed to identifiers that
look like but are not reference identifiers." - "...look like, but are not..."

"Any intermediate values are not reference identifiers and MUST NOT be treated
as such. [...] However, an application might define a process for
authenticating these intermediate identifiers in a way that then allows them to
be used as a reference identifier; see for example [SMTP-TLS]." -  erm... I
know what you are trying to say here (at least I think that I do), but, as
written this seems logically inconsistant.  Perhaps something like: "Unless an
application defines a process for authenticating intermediate identifiers in a
way that then allows them to be used as a reference identifier (see for example
[SMTP-TLS]), any intermediate values are not reference identifiers and MUST NOT
be treated as such."... or something...

Question:
"Note also that by policy, Top-Level Domains ([DNS-TERMS]) do not start with a
digit (see Section 2.2.1.3.2 of [ICANN-AGB]); ..." - yup, that does indeed seem
to be the current policy, but another round of new TLDs seems imminent and it
isn't clear (to me at least) that this will always be true. Should the document
note that this is not set in stone?

Notes:
I agree with Eric's comments / suggestions re: support of the new SVCB
(draft-ietf-dnsop-svcb-https) mechanism. Unless there is a really good reason
to not mention it, it seems like it should be discussed.

I'd also like to thank the DNSDIR ( Petr Špaček -
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/review-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-12-dnsdir-lc-spacek-2023-06-21/) and OPSDIR ( Quin Wu -
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/review-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis-08-opsdir-early-wu-2022-12-16/) for their helpful reviews, and to the authors for working with them to address the comments.

comments.body: I could have sworn that I included this in some other recent PR.  Oh well.

pulls.title: Tighten the wildcard rules
pulls.author: richsalz
pulls.body:
No wildcard characters in presented identifiers.

The * must only be in the left-most label, and must be the first or only
character in that label.

This is the first part of what was in draft-use-san.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: merged locally; closing.

Could we separate out this change from the rest of the changes here? I feel like a verifier should be able to reject a certificate for any reason, but this seems counter to that. At the same time, I don't think we should immediately reject this change.
"part or all of a label" is more general than what is intended--only accepting wildcards as the entire leftmost label.
This is actually a weaker requirement than what modern verifiers implement. They only accept wildcard certificates where the leftmost label is exactly "*".
This language supports reverting the "MAY to MUST" change you made.
Are you sure that `*foo.example.com` isn't supported?
This isn't correct; see https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man3/X509_check_host.html for example.
yes you are right.  i will undo that.

> Are you sure that `*foo.example.com` isn't supported?

The Baseline Requirements define:

> Wildcard Certificate: A Certificate containing an asterisk (*) in the left‐most position of
any of the Subject Fully‐Qualified Domain Names contained in the Certificate.
>
> Wildcard Domain Name: A Domain Name consisting of a single asterisk character
followed by a single full stop character (“*.”) followed by a Fully‐Qualified Domain Name

See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1107791 for Firefox's behavior, at least back then when I implemented it.

See also https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=434960#c3: "Disallow support for a*.example.net, *a.example.net, and a*b.example.net in certificate wildcard handling," which appears to be the same.

I know my Rust webpki library always implements the strict "only *" form.
per following comment, this change is wrong; thanks.

> This isn't correct; see https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man3/X509_check_host.html for example.

OpenSSL might implement something different but I'm arguing that the stricter form should be the only one that is accepted.
@sleevi would be more up to date with what Chrome does. @mozkeeler would know what FIrefox does presently.
This is not just the webpki, but I get it. The WG will have to decide if "*foo.example.com" should be outlawed.

> OpenSSL might implement something different but I'm arguing that the stricter form should be the only one that is accepted.

https://github.com/richsalz/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/issues/3

@richsalz This came up during the drafting of RFC 6125, and captured in [Section 7.2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6125#section-7.2)

Ignoring Chrome and Firefox here (which behave as Brian said; a wildcard is only allowed if it's the entire label), since they're more narrowly focused on WebPKI, the whole-label-only is also reflected in Security.framework (used by macOS/iOS/tvOS/watchOS for all verifications). The story on Windows is more complicated, since it's varied over time, and the construction you mention used to be allowed, but isn't on more recent versions in their strict mode (but I believe some compatibility may be retained for LDAPS)

pulls.title: Remove rules about CN-ID
pulls.author: richsalz
pulls.body: Don't use the CN-ID as an identifier for server identity.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Merged locally and pushed.

reviews.author: briansmith
reviews.body: Some initial comments. I didn't go through the whole updated draft and look for missed changes yet.

comments.body: Is this intended to be in this PR? It looks unrelated. I see there are a lot of changes to quotes in this PR. Perhaps we should do those changes in a separate PR that focuses on such reformatting, and then rebase this on top of that or vice versa.

As was discussed previously on the mailing list, recommending or disallowing CAs to include CN-IDs in the subject CN is a separate issue from requiring relying parties to only use subjectAltName when validating a certificate for a DNS name.

At our strictest, I think we should continue to allow CAs to include any DNS name in subject CN that also appears (verbatim) in the subjectAltName as a dNSName or iPAddress.

Or, perhaps we just don't make any recommendations at all regarding the contents of the subject CN. The main purpose of revising this RFC is to make the subject CN irrelevant as far as certificate verification is concerned.

I don't understand how the browser gets "w3.example.com" from "www.example.com" here. Typical operation of a web browser would be to only have "www.example.com," no?

I think in this PR we should stick to removing the CN-ID from this example, changing "two reference identifiers" to "one reference identifier".

If we want to say something about more exotic name resolution stuff for web browsers, we should do that in a separate PR.
I think this change should be reverted or moved to a formatting-only PR.

comments.body: This sentence does not parse well, and needs work.

The final clause ", known as ..." does not have a referent in the preceding content.  It is also far from clear how 6125(bis) rules should be applied when verifying client certificates, since there is very rarely a prior notion of the "reference identifier" against which to compare the presented identifiers when doing client authentication.

With STARTTLS one can imagine some pre-agreed identity exchanged prior to mutual TLS that server can then verify, but otherwise, all there are are just the presented identifiers, and the server can authorise or not authorise these for particular client requests.

So I'm not sure that imputing symmetry of roles in "mutual TLS" is reasonable. Generally I find that mutual TLS is often misunderstood, precisely by assuming the sort of symmetry that isn't actually there...

The terms "client" and "server" were correct as written, but perhaps worth saying somewhere that these are TLS-layer roles, and that the application could support the TLS server making requests of the TLS client after the TLS handshake, there is no requirement that the roles at that layer match the TLS-layer roles.

comments.body:
This is a bit of a nit, but since the reference is to IDNA-DEFS, perhaps it makes sense to keep the sequence ("visually similar characters") together, since that's the title of Section 4.4, since we're not referencing UTR39 directly, which calls them Confusable

```suggestion
Allowing internationalized domain names can lead to visually similar characters, also
referred to as "confusables", being included within certificates. For discussion, see
for example {{IDNA-DEFS, Section 4.4}} and {{UTS-39}}.
```

UTS-39 is the primary reference for this these days, and it seems like it's been acceptable to ref informative (e.g. [RFC 5894](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5894#ref-Unicode-UTS39)) or normative (e.g. [RFC 8266](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8266#ref-UTS39))

I realize this reintroduces the quotes you were getting rid of, but that seems to be the proper plural noun used to refer to these characters (e.g. 4.1, 4.2, and 6.1 of UTS 39). I'm less attached to the quotes, to be clear, but was trying to make some indicator of this being the actual term of art used.

```suggestion
(SNI) extension as discussed in {{TLS, Section 4.4.2.2}}.  If multiple
protocols share the same port, the client MUST use the Application-Layer
Protocol Negotiation as described in {{ALPN}} if the intended protocol has
registered Protocol ID {{SOME-REF-HERE}}.
```

Where {{SOME-REF-HERE}} would be reference to https://www.iana.org/assignments/tls-extensiontype-values/tls-extensiontype-values.xhtml#alpn-protocol-ids

There's probably a better way to smith this, and as (about to be) discussed on the list, this could be seen as superfluous.
Yeah, I dropped ALPN completely.
Thanks!  I took this wording, and added uts-39 as informative given the text above.

reviews.author: sleevi
reviews.body: Will follow-up on list

comments.body:
```suggestion
domains or protocols. TLS Extensions such as TLS Server
Name Identification (SNI), discussed in {{TLS, Section 4.4.2.2}},
and Application Layer Protocol Negotiation (ALPN), discussed in
{{ALPN}}, provide a way for the application to indicate the desired
identifier and protocol to the server, which can be used to select
the most appropriate certificate.
```

Note: GitHub won't allow suggestion to unmodified text, so this is roughly replacing the entire paragraph.

```markdown
This specification allows multiple DNS-IDs, SRV-IDs, or URI-IDs in a
certificate, which allows for a single application service to use the
same certificate for multiple identifiers. This enables a single certificate
to be used across multiple hostnames, such as when a client does not
support the TLS SNI extension, or across multiple protocols, such as
SMTP and HTTP, on a single hostname. The use of a single certificate
and public/private keypair in such environments MAY facilitate
cross-protocol attacks, particularly when used in differing TLS
configurations. See, for example, {{ALPCA}}, {{DROWN}}. Server
operators SHOULD take steps to mitigate the risk of cross-protocol
attacks, such as ensuring all TLS endpoints using a given certificate
support exactly the same TLS version(s) and ciphersuite(s), and
SHOULD make use of the TLS ALPN extension to ensure the correct
protocol is used.

## Multiple Reference Identifiers

This specification describes how a client may construct multiple
acceptable reference identifiers, and may match any of those reference
identifiers with the set of presented identifiers. {{PKIX, Section 4.2.1.10}}
describes a mechanism to allow CA certificates to be constrained in the
set of presented identifiers that they may include within server certificates.
However, these constraints only apply to the explicitly enumerated name
forms. For example, a CA that is only name constrained for DNS-IDs is not
constrained for SRV-IDs and URI-IDs, unless those name forms are also
explicitly included within the name constraints extension.

A client that constructs multiple reference identifiers of different types,
such as both DNS-ID and SRV-IDs, as described in
{#verify-reference-rules}, SHOULD take care to ensure that CAs issuing
such certificates are appropriately constrained. This MAY take the form of
local policy through agreement with the issuing CA, or MAY be enforced by
the client requiring that if one form of presented identifier is constrained,
such as a dNSName name constraint for DNS-IDs, then all other forms of
acceptable reference identities are also constrained, such as requiring a
uniformResourceIndicator name constraint for URI-IDs.
```

This is a huge mouthful, and is really meant to be a rough draft for starting discussion, because it definitely reads awkwardly. However, it tries to get the concept out, but I'm not entirely sure on the usage of the 2119 language here either.
I moved this into its own PR, #33.  I did a light editing pass and think the use of 2119 is fine.

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body: I like the new section on multiple reference identities.  I think that the ALPACA defense here could be more direct though.

comments.body:
This bit is soft.

1. There is no normative language about having the same versions and configuration (it's also key exchange methods, by the way), which is OK, but only if you explain why this is the case.  We make this suggestion because a deployment that can be attacked in this way might be vulnerable based on the weakest configuration it is willing to negotiate.  Though TLS guarantees that a connection will choose the server's choice from mutually-supported features, in a cross-protocol attack the attack might steer clients toward a server that has a weaker configuration.

2. the SHOULD on ALPN is really the crux of the cross-protocol defense though.  the key is that ALPN provides an authenticated way for the client and server to agree on the protocol that is in use.  that trumps anything else here.  if you have that, then the crypto configuration stuff is more or less pointless.

I would commit to doing this properly by starting a new section on how to manage the cross-protocol thing.  Focus on ALPACA there.  Not doing ALPN is only OK to the extent that the protocols that might be used cannot be misinterpreted and that's not an easy thing to guarantee, thanks to "robust" or creative interpretation of protocol elements being commonplace.

For this section, concentrate on the SNI issue.  Not doing SNI is mostly OK in protocols that unambiguously identify the identity they are using (HTTP's Host header field, for instance).  Not doing SNI in protocols without clear identity signals in-protocol - signals that are really used, everywhere - is just as bad as not doing ALPN.

The DROWN thing is definitely a risk, but DROWN was due to the configuration including options that were too weak to ensure that the TLS guarantee.  You might mention DROWN and emphasize that certain types of weakness in crypto can undermine the guarantee TLS provides about its negotiation of parameters, but it doesn't really belong here from what I can see.

```suggestion
such as both DNS-ID and SRV-IDs, as described in {{verify-reference-rules}},
```

```
A **client** that constructs multiple reference identifiers of different 
types ... SHOULD take care to ensure that CAs issuing such certificates 
are appropriately constrained. This MAY take the form of local policy 
through agreement with the issuing CA, or ...
```
I do not understand this. How can a _client_ make any requirements on a CA ?
Perhaps the two "SHOULD take care ... appropriately constrained. This MAY ... issuing CA" stipulations are intended to be about the _server_ that is presenting the certs it has obtained from a CA?  Even then, it seems to me (IIUC!) the first stipulation ought to be something more like "...ensure the certs obtained from the CA(s) are appropriately constrained.", because I'm not sure what is meant by constraining a CA.  Also, even then, I'm not sure how local policy might figure into this, but am of course not anywhere near as informed about this stuff as @sleevi is.

The portion beginning with "... or MAY be enforced by the client requiring ..." seems to make sense to me.

@equalsJeffH Ultimately, the client dictates the policies with respect to the CAs it will accept. This is a little inverted from the X.500 model where the server sets the policies, but whether it be directly via root programs or indirectly through rejecting such CAs, the client sets some degree of policy.

The “SHOULD take care” makes no sense as a server requirement; the server only cares that the client accepts.

And the “local policy” was intended to reflect the concepts of TAMP (RFC 6024), which although few practically implement via TAMP, many implementations exist to restrict CAs according to local CA policy decisions.

```suggestion
domains or protocols. TLS Extensions such as TLS Server Name Indication
```

```suggestion
to indicate the desired identifier and protocol to the server, which it
can then use to select the most appropriate certificate.
```
*differing* does not seem to be quite the right word, not exactly clear what this is getting at, either drop the clause (particularly when ...), or add more detail?  Unless a better word nails it???

I also find this text questionable.  If name constraints on DNS-ID don't constrain SRV-ID, then that is either a failure of the parent CA to also specify SRV-ID constraints, or a failure of the client's X.509 library to implement a suitably broad interpretation of DNS-ID constraints and apply them to anything that contains a DNS name.  I don't see any role here for servers to shop around for some alternative CA.
Or simply constrain DNS name *components* of these other name forms. Rejecting a CA for having just DNS-ID constraints and not others seems counterproductive.

> If name constraints on DNS-ID don't constrain SRV-ID, 

Per RFC5280, they don’t. So any standards-conforming client will have this behaviour.

I’m unaware of any client that broadens these constraints, other than applying dNS to CN, which is unspecified (and controversial), or email is with rfc822Name (which is defined).

I don’t disagree a client _could_ do this, but it also opens up other questions that this text tries to close/address, such as should a URI-ID constraint (which can express different semantics) be applied to DNS-IDs? Should DNS-IDs be applied to email addresses? We should, and can, avoid that morass.

> then that is either a failure of the parent CA to also specify SRV-ID constraints, 

Not with how nameConstraints are specified. Recall that nameConstraints implicitly allow any unconstrained name. If the CA certificate was issued prior to SRV-IDs being mainstream, or even standardized, there is no failure by the CA at play.

> or a failure of the client's X.509 library to implement a suitably broad interpretation of DNS-ID constraints and apply them to anything that contains a DNS name.

“Suitably broad” -> non standard and ill-defined. This attempts to at least provide some standard guidance in a way that’s interoperable and easily deployed.

“Counterproductive” is a bit confusing, because it assumes some goal being thwarted? Does the reply in https://github.com/richsalz/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/pull/33/files/a7fa0a163000655c971178736c74e379dd905af3#r839098404 help clarify how the above behavior is the most readily implemented solution with the closest alignment to the existing standards?

While it does impose a process above and beyond RFC 5280, it does so in a way solely on the outputs of the validation algorithm, without requiring alterations to the name validation. That is, you can examine the chain to see if any CAs meet the constraint described here, without having to actually process any validation in the client. That seems optimal from a deployability perspective?
Per the referenced attacks, service 1 allowing protocols A and B, while service 2 allowing protocols B and C, resulting in confused deputies.
I also find the "can be protected with a *good enough* client" not a compelling argument.

> If name constraints on DNS-ID don't constrain SRV-ID, then that is either a failure of the parent CA to also specify SRV-ID constraints,

Yes. And failures/mistakes happen, and this document gives advice on how to prevent being affected by that.

> or a failure of the client's X.509 library to implement a suitably broad interpretation of DNS-ID constraints and apply them to anything that contains a DNS name.

And now we seem to be heading down to the "looks like a DNS name in the CN RDN" area.  Slightly better since srv-id's are structured, but still, certificates are typed data and we should not have to guess at the semantics of fields.

> > or a failure of the client's X.509 library to implement a suitably broad interpretation of DNS-ID constraints and apply them to anything that contains a DNS name.
> 
> And now we seem to be heading down to the "looks like a DNS name in the CN RDN" area. Slightly better since srv-id's are structured, but still, certificates are typed data and we should not have to guess at the semantics of fields.

If the standards fail to extend the semantics of DNS-ID name constraints to cover other constructs that augment DNS names with additional context, then so much the worse for the standards. Perhaps it is time to admit that X.509 name constraints are a spectacular failure, that nobody uses and nobody should expect to work?
How about "conflicting" or "inconsistent"?

@vdukhovni I suspect it's out of scope in this document to declare X.509 name constraints a spectacular failure. We're trying to provide helpful implementation and deployment advice given the facts on the ground.
Either one is fine with me.
went with inconsistent.  resolving this.

> @vdukhovni I suspect it's out of scope in this document to declare X.509 name constraints a spectacular failure. 

master of understatement :)

I'm going to mark this as resolved, since it seems the main concern is "5280 is wrong"
Marking this as resolved.  5280 doesn't say nameConstraints applies to SRV-ID's, and that's the rules this draft has to operate within.
I have copied this comment into https://github.com/richsalz/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/issues/43

comments.body:
Q: Isn't the usual editorial practice to expand the acronym fully on first use, and then use the acronym in subsequent usages?

I suspect this may get flagged in the editorial queue; I fully agree with changing the subsequent uses, but perhaps keeping these two (and line 172) is sufficient?

In thinking in terms of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5280#section-2.2 and https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5280#section-2.3 , and in line with the editorial tweak, it _might_ make sense to

```suggestion
reference identity so it can deterministically and automatically authenticate the communication.
```

That may be overkill though :) It is somewhat implicit in the "Out of Scope", but this just tries to tie it back as a positive scope expression rather than negative.

Was "relative domain name" (line 297) meant to be "Relative Distinguished Name"? I wasn't sure, and the expression makes sense with either, but wanted to flag (since "Naming of Application Services" doesn't get into the relativity discussion)

```suggestion
client's communication with the server. This removes
DNS and DNS resolution from the attack surface.
```

It's a suggestion. It feels a bit colloquial, but it could be entirely fine as-is, so feel free to reject :)

Did you also want to update (new) lines 632/633?

I was originally surprised by this edit, but with the overall simplifications for CN handling, and this definition is unambiguously present, I like this approach you're taking here. I could see an argument for 632/633 being similarly redundant, or I could see the argument for making sure to restate (during the high level) that these come from the certificate.

Just wanted to flag
"as a service" is today a buzzword-bingo term that may be misunderstood. You may want to delete those words.
ALPN may belong here too.
Good point, done.

> ALPN may belong here too.

Not sure what you mean.  Do you mean something like adding ", or as an ALPN {{ALPN}} identifier" ?
it's good, merging.
6125 says "relative domain names". To avoid the ambiguity I changed it to "or other".
I like the emphasis; merging.
I'll let the RFC Editor decide which terms are commonplace and which need expansion on first use, unless you feel strongly.

>I could see the argument for making sure to restate (during the high level) that these come from the certificate.

That was my intent, because I think some folks will just cut/paste the steps into their internal docs :)

In some scenarios ALPN is the "formal identifier for an application protocol".  I need to re-read the full text to see if this was just a stupid comment or something that makes sense. The "may" in my statement indicates that I was unsure. :-)

`a URI scheme {{URI}}, a DNS SRV Service {{DNS-SRV}} or an ALPN {{ALPN}} identifier.`

I think that's a better definition.
Agreed, thanks!

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body:
This is the hard part because it hits a lot of the core concepts of the document.

I think that what this means is that we need to be more precise about the provenance of reference identifiers.  The current language in Section 6.1.1 is a bit wishy-washy.

comments.body:
I think that this is a bigger issue that this is just being exposed by this change.

The document talks about reference identifiers, but doesn't really go into much detail about how those are created.  I think that you already have much of what you need in Section 6.1.1.

Where it says:

> The client might need to extract the source domain and application service type from the input(s) it has received. 

You might instead say:

> This document doesn't precisely define how reference identifiers are derived.Applications that use this document need to define how reference identifiers are determined.  The security of a system that uses this document will depend on how reference identifiers are obtained.

Then back to the existing language:

> Naturally, if the inputs themselves are invalid or corrupt (e.g., a user has clicked a link provided by a malicious entity in a phishing attack), then the client might end up communicating with an unexpected application service.

Then for this text, we have a case where the system might handle an identifier that *looks* like a reference identifier, but it isn't.  What we're really saying here is:

> During the course of processing, a client might be exposed to identifiers that look like reference identifiers.  For example, DNS resolution that starts at a DNS-ID reference identifier might produce intermediate domain names that need to be further resolved.
>
> Any intermediate values are not reference identifiers and MUST NOT be treated as such, except as defined by the application.  In the DNS case, not treating intermediate domain names as reference identifiers removes DNS and DNS resolution from the attack surface.  An application might define a process for authenticating these intermediate identifiers in a way that then allows them to be used as a reference identifier; see for example {{?RFC8689}}.

Hi Martin, my apologies about the one-month delay in replying. Although much of your text seems fine, I suspect that this topic should be addressed in a separate issue/PR because, as you say, it was lurking all along and has merely been exposed by adding support for the IP-ID type.
Now see https://github.com/richsalz/draft-ietf-uta-rfc6125bis/issues/63
P.S. If the changes in this PR are acceptable to @richsalz then I suggest we merge it and deal with the reference identifier issue separately.
P.P.S. If this approach seems sensible, we can resolve this particular conversation before the merge. :-)
